title: Ghost Photography Tips for Tours
content:
Ghost photos are easy to take and hard to interpret. Low light, movement, dust, and moisture create artifacts that look convincing until you understand what caused them. I've reviewed hundreds of photos from tours. Most "ghosts" disappear once you understand the conditions under which the photo was taken.

Can you actually photograph ghosts?

There is no reliable method for photographing ghosts directly. What cameras capture are light, motion, and noise—sometimes in surprising ways. Photography on ghost tours should be approached as documentation, not proof. Skeptics often appreciate understanding the technical explanations behind supposed anomalies.

What camera settings work best at night?

High ISO, wide aperture, and slower shutter speeds help capture detail in low light. The trade-off is noise and motion blur. Manual control matters more than expensive gear. Understanding your camera's limits is key. For phone cameras:
  • Enable night mode if available
  • Keep the phone steady during capture
  • Avoid digital zoom
  • Clean the lens before shooting

Should you use flash on ghost tours?

Flash often creates false positives. Dust, insects, and moisture reflect light back into the lens, creating orbs and streaks. Most guides discourage flash because it disrupts atmosphere and other participants. On walking tours and cemetery tours, flash can also be disrespectful to other visitors.

What are common photo artifacts that aren't ghosts?

Orbs, mist, light streaks, and reflections account for most anomalies. Lens flare and sensor noise are especially common on phones. Common causes:
  • Orbs – Dust, pollen, or moisture close to the lens
  • Light streaks – Camera movement during long exposure
  • Mist – Breath in cold air, humidity, or fog
  • Reflections – Glass, polished surfaces, or water
Reviewing metadata and shooting multiple frames helps identify artifacts.

Photography on different tour types

Different formats create different photography challenges:
  • Walking tours – Constant movement; use burst mode at stops
  • Cemetery tours – Better for atmospheric shots; respect grave sites
  • Investigation tours – Controlled environments; coordinate with equipment use
  • Bus tours – Window reflections problematic; shoot during stops

How do you review ghost photos?

Always review photos later, not on-site. Compare multiple shots, check environmental conditions, and look for consistency. Single images without context are rarely meaningful.

What if you capture something unexplained?

Unexplained doesn't mean paranormal. It means you lack enough data to explain it yet. Good investigators document, compare, and withhold conclusions. If you want to learn more about systematic investigation, see our guide to paranormal investigation tours.

Best cities for ghost photography

Some cities offer particularly photogenic haunted locations:
  • Savannah – Spanish moss, historic squares, atmospheric lighting
  • New Orleans – Ornate ironwork, narrow streets, dramatic shadows
  • Edinburgh – Medieval architecture, candlelit closes
  • Charleston – Historic homes, garden gates, gas lanterns

Practical Takeaway

Ghost photography is about observation, not evidence. Understanding your camera reduces false positives and makes real documentation more meaningful. For equipment context, see our ghost hunting equipment guide. For a complete overview of tour formats, start with the complete ghost tour guide. Whether you capture something unexplainable or simply come away with striking photographs of historic architecture at night, the skills you develop through ghost photography transfer directly to low-light and atmospheric photography in general. Bring a tripod, keep your lens clean, and stay skeptical of your own results.
